sentence: Twitter ( TWTR ) is testing the 'Buy' option in its tweets that enables users to shop.
As part of this process, the company recently selected a small number of U.S. users, who will now be able to purchase goods from merchants by tapping the Buy button.
Reportedly, the selected few include music stars like Eminem, Keith Urban and Brad Paisley, retailers Home Depot ( HD ) and Burberry and non-profits such as The Nature Conservancy and GLAAD.
Twitter has partnered with Fancy, Gumroad, Musictoday and Stripe as platforms for the initial testing phase.
Per Twitter, the Buy button will gradually be rolled-out to other users.
The company believes that the new feature will help it to become a leading ecommerce provider over the long run.
Twitter's growing user base makes it a formidable platform for ecommerce offerings.
At the end of the second quarter, the company had 271 million users.
More importantly, Mobile MAUs (78% of total MAUs) jumped 29% year over year to 211 million.
For some time, Twitter had been gearing up to enter the ecommerce bandwagon.
Earlier, the company partnered with Starbucks, American Express and Amazon.com ( AMZN ) to offer ecommerce services.
We believe that the experience of those early collaborations will help Twitter to offer a smooth and secured ecommerce platform, going forward.
In July, Twitter bought CardSpring that facilitates connection among merchants and payment processors.
CardSpring's ecommerce platform links card users' account to merchants which helps in tracking user card swipes.
It also helps merchants to know the effectiveness of online promotions on offline sales and offer targeted ads.

Per eMarketer, global business-to-consumer (B2C) ecommerce sales will increase 20.1% to $1.5 trillion in 2014 and hit $2.4 trillion by 2017, which presents a significant growth opportunity for Twitter.
As competition intensifies in the advertising market, ecommerce opens up a new revenue source for Twitter.
However, we believe that Twitter will face significant competition in this market, particularly from Facebook ( FB ) which enjoys a significant leverage due to massive user base.
